canonical_explanation.text: Food provides nutrients that our body needs. Carbohydrates (rice, bread) give energy. Proteins (milk, eggs, pulses) help in growth and repair. Fats (butter, oil) provide energy and warmth. Vitamins and minerals protect from diseases. A balanced diet includes all nutrients in the right amounts. Digestion begins in the mouth where teeth chew food and saliva mixes with it. Food travels through the food pipe to the stomach where it is churned. The small intestine absorbs nutrients into blood, and the large intestine absorbs water. We have four types of teeth: incisors (cut), canines (tear), premolars and molars (grind).
rules: Proteins help in growth and repair (milk, eggs, pulses)
Fats provide energy and keep body warm (butter, oil)
Vitamins and minerals protect from diseases
A balanced diet includes all nutrients
Digestion starts in the mouth with teeth and saliva
Stomach churns and mixes food with digestive juices
Small intestine absorbs nutrients into blood
Large intestine absorbs water and forms waste
Incisors cut, canines tear, molars grind food

questions.question_text: Which nutrient provides energy to our body?
questions.explanation_correct: Carbohydrates like rice, bread, and pasta provide energy to our body. They are the main source of fuel that gives us the energy to play, study, and do other activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vitamins, minerals, and water are important for our health, but they do not directly provide energy to our body. Carbohydrates are the nutrients that get converted into energy that powers our muscles and organs.

questions.question_text: Which of these foods is rich in proteins?
questions.explanation_correct: Eggs are rich in proteins, which help our body grow and repair itself. Proteins are important nutrients that our body needs to stay healthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rice, potatoes, and sugar do not contain a lot of proteins. Proteins are mainly found in foods like eggs, milk, pulses, and meat. Eggs are a great source of proteins that our body can use to grow and stay strong.

questions.question_text: Fats help to:

options.text: Store energy and keep the body warm

questions.explanation_correct: Fats help to store energy and keep the body warm because they are a concentrated source of energy. When the body uses this stored energy, it also produces heat to keep the body warm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct. Fats do not help build bones, which is the job of minerals like calcium. Fats also do not fight diseases, which is the role of vitamins and minerals. Fats are not involved in the digestion of food, which is done by enzymes and other digestive processes.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a source of carbohydrates?
questions.explanation_correct: Rice is a source of carbohydrates, which provide energy for our body. Carbohydrates are found in foods like bread, pasta, and potatoes as well.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Butter is a source of fat, not carbohydrates. Fats provide energy and warmth, but they are different from carbohydrates. Fish and cheese are also not sources of carbohydrates - they are sources of protein, which helps in growth and repair of our body.

questions.question_text: Proteins are needed for:
questions.explanation_correct: Proteins are needed for growth and repair of the body. They help build and maintain our muscles, bones, and other tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Proteins do not just give energy. They are important for helping your body grow and repair itself. Fats and carbohydrates are the main sources of energy in food. Proteins are not primarily used for keeping the body warm or making bones strong, though they do play a role in those functions as well.

questions.question_text: A balanced diet contains:

options.text: All nutrients in the right amounts

questions.explanation_correct: A balanced diet contains all the different types of nutrients like carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, and minerals in the right amounts. This helps our body get all the nutrition it needs to be healthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A balanced diet does not just contain one type of nutrient like proteins or carbohydrates. It has a mix of all the different types of nutrients our body needs in the right proportions. This ensures our body gets all the energy, growth, and protection it requires.

questions.question_text: Digestion begins in the:
questions.explanation_correct: Digestion begins in the mouth because that's where we chew our food with our teeth and mix it with saliva. This helps break down the food so it can be digested properly in the rest of the digestive system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Digestion does not begin in the stomach, small intestine, or large intestine. These are all part of the digestive system, but the first stage of digestion happens in the mouth when we chew our food and mix it with saliva. The mouth is where digestion starts before the food travels to the other parts of the digestive system.

questions.question_text: Food travels from the mouth to the stomach through the:
questions.explanation_correct: The food pipe, also called the esophagus, is the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach. This is the correct path that food travels through after leaving the mouth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Food does not travel through the small intestine, large intestine, or rectum to reach the stomach. These are all parts of the digestive system, but they come after the stomach, not before it. The food pipe or esophagus is the correct pathway that food takes from the mouth to the stomach.

questions.question_text: Where are nutrients absorbed into the blood?
questions.explanation_correct: The small intestine is the place where nutrients from the food are absorbed into the bloodstream. This is because the small intestine has a very large surface area and special structures that help absorb all the important nutrients from the digested food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mouth, stomach, and large intestine are not the main places where nutrients are absorbed into the blood. In the mouth, food is just chewed and mixed with saliva. In the stomach, food is further broken down but not absorbed. The large intestine mostly absorbs water from the leftover waste. The small intestine is the main place where all the important nutrients from the food are taken into the bloodstream to be used by the body.

questions.question_text: What is absorbed in the large intestine?
questions.explanation_correct: The large intestine absorbs water from the remaining food waste. This is important to prevent dehydration and keep our body balanced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The large intestine does not absorb proteins, fats, or carbohydrates. These nutrients are mostly absorbed in the small intestine. The large intestine's main job is to absorb water from the leftover waste material, so the correct answer is water.

questions.question_text: Which teeth are used to cut food?
questions.explanation_correct: The incisors are the front teeth that are used to cut and bite food. They have sharp edges that help us chew and tear the food we eat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The molars, canines, and premolars are not used to cut food. The molars and premolars are the flat teeth at the back of the mouth that are used to grind and chew food. The canines are the pointed teeth next to the incisors that are used to tear food. Only the incisors, the sharp front teeth, are used to cut food.

questions.question_text: The pointed teeth used for tearing food are called:
questions.explanation_correct: The pointed teeth used for tearing food are called canines. Canines have a sharp, pointed shape that helps in tearing and ripping food, especially meat, when we chew.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incisors, or front teeth, are used for cutting and biting food. The molars, at the back of the mouth, are used for grinding and chewing food into smaller pieces. The premolars, in the middle, also help in grinding food. But the canines, which are the pointed teeth on the sides, are specially used for tearing and ripping food.

questions.question_text: How many permanent teeth does an adult have?
questions.explanation_correct: An adult has 32 permanent teeth. This includes 4 incisors, 2 canines, 4 premolars, and 6 molars in both the upper and lower jaw, making a total of 32 teeth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option C, 32 permanent teeth, is the correct answer. Adults do not have 20 teeth (option A) or 28 teeth (option B) or 36 teeth (option D). The full set of adult teeth includes 4 incisors, 2 canines, 4 premolars, and 6 molars in both the upper and lower jaw, which adds up to 32 permanent teeth.

questions.question_text: A growing child needs more proteins because proteins help in:
questions.explanation_correct: A growing child needs more proteins because proteins help in growing taller and stronger. Proteins are important for building and repairing tissues in the body, which is why they are essential for a child's growth and development.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct. Proteins do not directly help in staying warm, running faster, or sleeping better. While these things are important, the primary role of proteins is to help the body grow and become stronger, which is why option B is the right answer.

questions.question_text: Rohan only eats chips and chocolates every day. What is wrong with his diet?

options.text: It is not balanced - missing important nutrients

questions.explanation_correct: Rohan's diet is not balanced because it is missing important nutrients like proteins, vitamins, and minerals that our body needs. Eating only chips and chocolates every day is not healthy as it does not provide a variety of nutrients.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rohan's diet is not balanced because it has too many carbohydrates and fats from the chips and chocolates, but it is missing other important nutrients like proteins, vitamins, and minerals. A balanced diet should have the right amounts of all the different nutrients our body needs to stay healthy.

questions.question_text: Why should we chew our food properly?

options.text: To break it into smaller pieces for easier digestion

questions.explanation_correct: We should chew our food properly because it breaks the food into smaller pieces. This makes it easier for the digestive system to break down the food and absorb the nutrients.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A and C are incorrect because chewing food properly is not about making it taste better or making teeth stronger. Option D is incorrect because chewing food properly is about making digestion easier, not just making eating slower.

questions.question_text: The stomach churns food and mixes it with digestive juices. Why is this important?
questions.explanation_correct: The stomach churns food and mixes it with digestive juices because this helps to break down the food further. This is important so that the nutrients in the food can be absorbed by the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The stomach churns food and mixes it with digestive juices, not to make the food taste better, colorful or keep it warm. Instead, this process helps to break down the food into smaller pieces so that the nutrients can be absorbed by the body more easily.

questions.question_text: When you bite into an apple, which teeth do you use first?
questions.explanation_correct: When you bite into an apple, you use your incisors first. Incisors are the front teeth that are sharp and used for cutting and biting into food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are molars, canines, and premolars. Molars are the back teeth used for grinding food, canines are the pointed teeth used for tearing food, and premolars are between the incisors and molars used for both cutting and grinding. But when biting into an apple, you use your incisors, which are the sharp front teeth designed for cutting into food.

questions.question_text: An athlete running a marathon needs lots of energy. Which type of food should they eat before the race?
questions.explanation_correct: Rice and pasta are carbohydrates, which provide energy for the body. Since the athlete needs lots of energy to run a marathon, eating carbohydrate-rich foods like rice and pasta is the best choice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Butter and oil are fats, which provide energy but not as quickly as carbohydrates. Vitamins and water are important for health, but they do not provide the immediate energy needed for a marathon. The athlete should choose carbohydrate-rich foods like rice and pasta to get the energy they need for the race.

questions.question_text: Which meal is most balanced?

options.text: Roti, dal, vegetable, curd, and fruit

questions.explanation_correct: The answer B is the most balanced meal because it includes a variety of foods like roti (carbohydrate), dal (protein), vegetable (vitamins and minerals), curd (dairy), and fruit (vitamins and minerals). This gives the body all the different nutrients it needs to stay healthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not balanced meals. Option A (dal and rice) only has carbohydrates and proteins, but is missing other important nutrients. Option C (chips and cola) has mostly fats and sugars, which are not enough for a healthy diet. Option D (bread and butter) has carbohydrates and fats, but is missing other essential nutrients.

questions.question_text: Saliva in the mouth helps to:

options.text: Make food wet and start digestion

questions.explanation_correct: Saliva in the mouth helps to make the food wet and start the digestion process. Saliva contains enzymes that start breaking down the food, making it easier to swallow and digest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Saliva does not add color to food, it is clear. Saliva also does not make teeth stronger or keep the tongue clean. The main function of saliva is to make the food wet and start the digestion process by breaking down the food with enzymes.

questions.question_text: A lion tears meat with its teeth. Which teeth does it mainly use?
questions.explanation_correct: Lions have sharp, pointed canine teeth that they mainly use to tear and rip meat. The canines are perfect for this job, as they can easily cut through tough meat and flesh.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lions do not use their incisors, molars, or premolars to tear meat. Incisors are for cutting and biting, molars are for grinding food, and premolars are a mix of the two. Canine teeth, with their sharp, pointed shape, are specially designed for tearing and ripping meat, which is why lions use them to eat their prey.

questions.question_text: Which statement about nutrients is correct?

options.text: Fats can be stored for later use
Vitamins are needed in large amounts

questions.explanation_correct: The statement 'Fats can be stored for later use' is correct. Fats are a type of nutrient that the body can store as fat in the body. This stored fat can be used later as a source of energy when the body needs it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'Carbohydrates build muscles' is incorrect. Carbohydrates are a type of nutrient that provides energy to the body, but they do not help in building muscles. Proteins are the nutrients that help in the growth and repair of muscles. The statement 'Proteins give instant energy' is also incorrect, as proteins are not a source of instant energy. Fats are the correct nutrient that can be stored for later use.

questions.question_text: The small intestine is longer than the large intestine because:

options.text: It needs more space to store food
It needs more surface area to absorb nutrients
It is closer to the mouth

questions.explanation_correct: The small intestine is longer than the large intestine because it needs more surface area to absorb all the nutrients from the food we eat. The longer the small intestine, the more it can absorb into the bloodstream.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The small intestine is not longer than the large intestine to store more food. It is longer to provide more surface area for nutrient absorption. The food moves from the stomach into the small intestine, where most of the digestion and nutrient absorption happens. The small intestine is around 20 feet long, while the large intestine is only about 5 feet long.

questions.question_text: Children have 20 milk teeth. When they grow up, they get 32 permanent teeth. What is the extra 12 teeth?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C - Premolars and wisdom teeth. When children grow up, they get 12 extra permanent teeth which are the premolars and wisdom teeth. Premolars help grind food, and wisdom teeth come later in life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The extra 12 teeth are not just extra incisors (A) or canines (B), as children only have a limited number of those teeth. The extra 12 teeth are also not just new molars (D) - they include the premolars and wisdom teeth which help with chewing and grinding food as the child grows older.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a source of fats?
questions.explanation_correct: Butter is a source of fats. Fats are one of the three main nutrients that our body needs, and they provide energy and warmth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rice, apples, and dal are not sources of fats. These are carbohydrates, fruits, and proteins respectively. Butter, on the other hand, is a type of fat that our body uses for energy and warmth.

questions.question_text: Why should we eat fruits and vegetables every day?
questions.explanation_correct: We should eat fruits and vegetables every day because they provide important vitamins and minerals that our body needs. Vitamins and minerals help protect us from getting sick and keep us healthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While fruits and vegetables may be tasty, colorful, and affordable, the main reason we should eat them every day is that they give us important vitamins and minerals. Vitamins and minerals are nutrients that our body needs to function properly and stay healthy. They help protect us from diseases and infections.

questions.question_text: What happens to undigested food in the body?

options.text: It stays in the stomach forever
It is removed as waste from the body

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C. Undigested food that cannot be absorbed by the body is removed as waste through the large intestine and out of the body as stool or poop. This is how the body gets rid of the parts of the food that it doesn't need.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect. Undigested food is not absorbed by the blood (A), it does not stay in the stomach forever (B), and it does not turn into blood (D). The body removes the leftover parts of the food that it cannot use through the large intestine and out of the body as waste.

questions.question_text: Which teeth are used to grind food?
questions.explanation_correct: The molars are the teeth that are used to grind food. They have a flat surface that helps in crushing and grinding the food into smaller pieces, making it easier for digestion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Incisors are used for cutting food, canines are used for tearing food, but the molars are the teeth that are used to grind food into smaller pieces. The molars have a flat surface that helps in this process, unlike the other teeth.

questions.question_text: Which is the correct order of organs in the digestive system?

options.text: Mouth - Stomach - Food pipe - Small intestine
Mouth - Food pipe - Stomach - Small intestine
Food pipe - Mouth - Stomach - Large intestine
Stomach - Mouth - Food pipe - Small intestine

questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of organs in the digestive system is Mouth - Food pipe - Stomach - Small intestine. Food first enters the mouth where it is chewed and mixed with saliva, then travels down the food pipe to the stomach, and finally reaches the small intestine where nutrients are absorbed into the bloodstream.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Mouth - Food pipe - Stomach - Small intestine. This is because food follows this path in the digestive system - it starts in the mouth, then goes down the food pipe, enters the stomach, and finally reaches the small intestine. The other options do not follow the correct sequence of the digestive organs.

questions.question_text: Carbohydrates provide energy to our body.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, carbohydrates like rice, bread, and pasta provide energy to our body. Our body can easily break down carbohydrates into glucose, which is used as fuel to power all our activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbohydrates do not provide energy to our body. That's not true. Carbohydrates are an important nutrient that our body can easily convert into glucose, which is the main source of energy for our cells and muscles.

questions.question_text: Proteins are found in rice and bread.
questions.explanation_correct: Proteins are not found in rice and bread. Proteins are found in foods like milk, eggs, and pulses, which help in growth and repair of the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rice and bread are carbohydrate-rich foods, which provide energy to the body. Proteins, which help in growth and repair, are found in foods like milk, eggs, and pulses, not in rice and bread.

questions.question_text: A balanced diet includes all types of nutrients.
questions.explanation_correct: A balanced diet includes all the different types of nutrients our body needs, like carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, and minerals. This ensures we get the right amount of each nutrient to stay healthy and strong.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A balanced diet does not always mean it includes every single type of food. It just means the diet has the right amounts of all the important nutrients our body needs, like carbohydrates for energy, proteins for growth, and vitamins to protect us from diseases.

questions.question_text: Digestion starts in the stomach.
questions.explanation_correct: Digestion actually starts in the mouth, not the stomach. When you chew food, your saliva mixes with it and starts breaking it down before it reaches the stomach.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Digestion does not start in the stomach. The process begins in the mouth, where your teeth chew the food and your saliva starts to break it down. The food then travels to the stomach, where the digestion continues.

questions.question_text: The small intestine absorbs nutrients from digested food.
questions.explanation_correct: The small intestine is where most of the digestion and absorption of nutrients happens. As the food moves through the small intestine, nutrients like carbohydrates, proteins, and vitamins get absorbed into the bloodstream to be used by the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The large intestine, not the small intestine, is where water is absorbed from the remaining food. The small intestine is where the nutrients from digested food are absorbed into the bloodstream to be used by the body. So the statement that the small intestine absorbs nutrients is true.

questions.question_text: Incisors are used for grinding food.
questions.explanation_correct: Incisors are used for cutting and biting food, not for grinding it. Molars and premolars are the teeth that grind up food into smaller pieces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Incisors are not used for grinding food. They have sharp edges that are used for cutting and biting food. The teeth that grind up food into smaller pieces are the molars and premolars at the back of your mouth.

questions.question_text: Eating only junk food is good for health.
questions.explanation_correct: Eating only junk food like chips, burgers, and candies is not good for health. Junk food has a lot of unhealthy fats, sugar, and salt but lacks important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and fiber that our body needs to stay healthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eating junk food may seem tasty, but it can make you sick in the long run. A healthy diet should have a balance of different types of foods like fruits, vegetables, grains, and proteins. This gives your body all the nutrients it needs to grow strong and fight diseases.

questions.question_text: Adults have 32 permanent teeth.
questions.explanation_correct: Adults have 32 permanent teeth. This is because as we grow older, our baby teeth fall out and are replaced by stronger, permanent teeth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some people think adults have fewer than 32 teeth, but that is not correct. We actually have 32 permanent teeth as adults. This includes 4 incisors, 2 canines, 4 premolars, and 6 molars in each jaw, making a total of 32 teeth.

questions.question_text: Water is mainly absorbed in the small intestine.
questions.explanation_correct: The main absorption of water happens in the large intestine, not the small intestine. The small intestine absorbs nutrients like carbohydrates, proteins, and vitamins, but it is the large intestine that absorbs the remaining water from the food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is a common misconception that water is mainly absorbed in the small intestine. However, this is not correct. The small intestine is where most of the nutrients from food are absorbed into the bloodstream. The large intestine is where the remaining water is absorbed from the leftover food, before it is excreted from the body as waste.

questions.question_text: Milk, eggs, and pulses are all good sources of proteins.
questions.explanation_correct: Milk, eggs, and pulses are all good sources of proteins. Proteins are important for growth and repair of our body, and these foods contain a lot of proteins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milk, eggs, and pulses are not all good sources of carbohydrates. Carbohydrates provide energy, but these foods are actually good sources of proteins, which help in growth and repair of our body.

questions.question_text: _____ provide energy to our body.
questions.explanation_correct: Carbohydrates are the main source of energy for our body. They are found in foods like rice, bread, and potatoes. When we eat these foods, our body breaks down the carbohydrates into a simple sugar called glucose, which is then used to give us energy to do all our activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Carbohydrates'. Carbohydrates are the nutrient that provides energy to our body. Foods like rice, bread, and potatoes are rich in carbohydrates. Other nutrients like proteins and fats also provide energy, but carbohydrates are the main source of energy for our body.

questions.question_text: _____ help in growth and repair of body tissues.
questions.explanation_correct: Proteins help in the growth and repair of body tissues. This is because proteins are the building blocks of our body and help in the formation and maintenance of muscles, bones, and other tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is Proteins. Proteins are the nutrients that help in the growth and repair of our body tissues. They are important for the development and maintenance of muscles, bones, and other parts of the body. Carbohydrates provide energy, while fats provide energy and warmth. Vitamins and minerals help protect us from diseases, but they do not directly help in growth and repair like proteins do.

questions.question_text: A diet that contains all nutrients in the right amounts is called a _____ diet.
questions.explanation_correct: A balanced diet contains all the nutrients we need, like carbohydrates for energy, proteins for growth, and vitamins to stay healthy. This ensures our body gets everything it needs in the right amounts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A 'balanced' diet means it has a good mix of all the nutrients our body needs, like carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins and minerals. This is the correct answer. A 'unbalanced' diet would be missing some important nutrients.

questions.question_text: Digestion begins in the _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Digestion begins in the mouth because that's where the process of breaking down food into smaller pieces starts. In the mouth, your teeth chew the food and your saliva mixes with it to help in the digestion process.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Digestion does not begin in the stomach. It starts in the mouth, where your teeth chew the food and your saliva helps break it down. The correct answer is 'mouth'.

questions.question_text: Food travels from the mouth to the stomach through the _____ pipe.
questions.explanation_correct: The food travels from the mouth to the stomach through the food pipe, also called the esophagus. This is the correct answer because the food needs to go through the food pipe to reach the stomach after being chewed in the mouth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'food'. The food you eat travels from the mouth to the stomach through the food pipe, not any other kind of pipe. The food pipe, or esophagus, is the tube that connects the mouth to the stomach and allows the food to move from one to the other.

questions.question_text: Nutrients are absorbed into the blood in the _____ intestine.
questions.explanation_correct: The small intestine is where most of the nutrients from the food we eat are absorbed into the bloodstream. This is because the small intestine has a large surface area with tiny finger-like projections called villi that help absorb the nutrients efficiently.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The large intestine is where water is absorbed from the remaining food matter, not the nutrients. The nutrients are absorbed in the small intestine, which has a very long and winding structure to maximize the absorption of all the important substances our body needs from the food we eat.

questions.question_text: The front teeth used for cutting food are called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The front teeth used for cutting food are called incisors. Incisors have sharp edges that help us bite and cut through food, like when we eat an apple or slice of bread.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The wrong answer would be something like 'canines' or 'molars'. Canines are the pointed teeth that help us tear food, while molars are the flat teeth at the back that grind and crush food. The front teeth that we use to cut food are called incisors.

questions.question_text: The pointed teeth used for tearing food are called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The pointed teeth used for tearing food are called canines. Canines are perfect for ripping and tearing food into smaller pieces that can be easily chewed and swallowed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The answer 'canines' is correct. Canines are the sharp, pointed teeth that are used for tearing and ripping food. They are located next to the incisors, which are the front teeth used for cutting food. The other teeth, such as the premolars and molars, are used for grinding and chewing food into smaller pieces.

questions.question_text: The _____ intestine absorbs water from undigested food.
questions.explanation_correct: The large intestine, also called the colon, is the final part of the digestive system. Its main job is to absorb water from the undigested food that is left over after the small intestine has taken out the nutrients.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The small intestine, not the large intestine, is where most of the digestion and absorption of nutrients takes place. The large intestine, on the other hand, is responsible for absorbing water from the undigested food that remains. So the correct answer is 'large' intestine.

questions.question_text: _____ in the mouth helps to make food wet and begins digestion.
questions.explanation_correct: Saliva in the mouth helps make food wet and begins the process of digestion. Saliva contains enzymes that start to break down the food as we chew it, making it easier for the stomach and intestines to continue digesting it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Saliva'. Saliva is a liquid produced in the mouth that helps to wet and soften the food we eat. This helps the teeth to chew and grind the food more easily. Saliva also contains enzymes that start to break down the food, beginning the process of digestion. Other things in the mouth, like the teeth, do not help to wet or break down the food in this way.

questions.question_text: _____ store energy and help keep the body warm.
questions.explanation_correct: Fats are a type of nutrient that stores energy in our body. They also help keep our body warm by providing insulation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Fats'. Fats are a type of nutrient that stores energy in our body and helps keep us warm. The other nutrients like carbohydrates and proteins do not have the same function of storing energy and providing warmth.

questions.question_text: Back teeth used for grinding food are called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The back teeth that we use to grind and crush our food are called molars. Molars have a flat, rough surface that helps break down the food into smaller pieces so that it can be easily digested.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The answer 'molars' is correct. Molars are the back teeth that we use to grind and crush our food. They have a flat, rough surface that helps break down the food into smaller pieces. The other types of teeth, such as incisors (front teeth) and canines (pointed teeth), are used for cutting and tearing food, but not for grinding it.

questions.question_text: Arrange the digestive organs in the order food travels through them:
questions.explanation_correct: The food travels through the mouth, then the food pipe, then the stomach, and finally the small intestine. This is the correct order because that is the path the food takes as it gets digested in your body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The food does not travel directly from the mouth to the small intestine. It goes through the food pipe and the stomach first before reaching the small intestine. The correct order is: mouth, food pipe, stomach, and then small intestine.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps of digestion in order:
ordering_items: Waste is removed from the body
Food is chewed in the mouth
Nutrients are absorbed in small intestine
Food is churned in the stomach
correct_answer: Food is chewed in the mouth
Food is churned in the stomach
Nutrients are absorbed in small intestine
Waste is removed from the body
questions.explanation_correct: The order of the steps of digestion is correct because it follows the logical sequence of food traveling through the body. First, food is chewed in the mouth, then it goes to the stomach where it is churned, next the small intestine absorbs the nutrients, and finally the waste is removed from the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: 'Waste is removed from the body', 'Food is chewed in the mouth', 'Food is churned in the stomach', 'Nutrients are absorbed in small intestine'. This is not correct because the waste is removed at the end, after the nutrients have been absorbed in the small intestine. The order should follow the path of food through the body.

questions.question_text: Arrange the types of teeth from front to back of the mouth:
questions.explanation_correct: The teeth are arranged in the order Incisors, Canines, Premolars, Molars from the front to the back of the mouth. This is because the incisors are the front teeth that cut food, the canines are the sharp teeth next to them that tear food, the premolars are the teeth behind the canines that grind food, and the molars are the largest teeth at the back that also grind food into smaller pieces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Molars, Incisors, Premolars, Canines. This is wrong because the incisors are the front teeth that cut food, the canines are the sharp teeth next to them that tear food, the premolars are the teeth behind the canines that grind food, and the molars are the largest teeth at the back that also grind food into smaller pieces. The teeth are arranged from front to back in the order: Incisors, Canines, Premolars, Molars.

questions.question_text: Arrange meals in order throughout a day:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of meals throughout the day is Breakfast, Lunch, Evening snack, and Dinner. This is because we need to start our day with a good Breakfast to get energy, then have Lunch in the middle of the day, followed by a light Evening snack, and end with a full Dinner at night.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Lunch, Breakfast, Dinner, Evening snack. This is not correct because we need to start our day with Breakfast to get energy, then have Lunch in the middle of the day, followed by a light Evening snack, and end with a full Dinner at night. The order of meals should be Breakfast, Lunch, Evening snack, and Dinner.

questions.question_text: Arrange nutrients by how much we need daily (most needed first):
questions.explanation_correct: We need the most carbohydrates in our daily diet because they provide the main source of energy for our body. Proteins are also needed in large amounts to help our body grow and repair itself. Vitamins are needed in smaller amounts but are important to protect us from diseases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order is Carbohydrates, Proteins, Vitamins. We need the most carbohydrates because they give us energy to play and learn. Proteins are also needed in large amounts to help us grow. Vitamins are needed in smaller amounts, but they are very important to keep us healthy and prevent diseases.
